interest, but they consist very largely of literal copies of papers published 
by the authors in the last four volumes of the <u>Reports of the British 
Association for the Advancement of Science “<\u>.
Thus 
1. - The Chapter “<u>On Copper and Iron in Green Oysters”<\u> (pages 
33-41) is substantially identical with the appendix to a paper 
published last year (B.A. Reports, 1898, pp. 562-569). Many 
paragraphs in the two are literally identical, and all the 
analytical tables, given in the present paper, are printed in 
full in the B.A. Report.
2.- <u>The opening section of the chapter on Microchemistry <\u> (pp.42.44)
is a <u>verbatim <\u> copy of the section <u>Investigation of the Pigment <\u>”
in B.A. Reports 1897 pp. 365 and 366.
3.- <u>The presence of copper especially in the leucocytes <\u> has been 
asserted already by the authors in Roy. Soc. proc. LXII. p. 30, and 
B. A. Reports 1897 p. 365, and no additional statements of 
importance are made in the present paper.
4.- Most of the statements on the growth of oysters in solutions 
of iron and copper salts (pp. 46-50) have been summarised 
in the B. A. Reports. The new statement,- that oysters grown 
for a long time in very dilute solutions of copper do take up that 
metal,- is not accompanied by detailed statements of 
analytical results. The quantities of copper dealt with are 
so minute that analytical details should in my opinion 
be given.
5.- <u>Chapter XI On the Connection between Oysters and Infection <\u> pp. 50-56
is an almost literal copy of the paper by the authors, published 
in B. A. Reports 1895, pp. 723-72. The only substantial 
alteration is the prefix of an unimportant introductory paragraph.
6.- <u>Chapter XIII, On the Bacteriology of the Oyster and other 
Shellfish <\u>, is in large part <s>[text?]<\s> copied, with only a few verbal 
alterations of slight importance, from B. A. Reports 1896
pp. 663-665 and <s>666<\s> 667-668. The substance of pp. 60-70
